author: Hobbythom
title: Sublime parts pack.. And a neat set
review:
Every year the Friends line has a few sets around the ten $/£/€ mark, featuring one of the girls and her hobby. And every year there is one that stands out as a parts pack for new or rare parts. Last year it was Emma's kiosk and this year it's Mia's beach scooter.

While the set by itself is a neat thing when constructed the highlight is the collection of parts: a new color for the scooter, two surfboards (of which one is printed) and a hairpiece which previously has appeared in only one other set. Wether you are a town or friends builder, this set is not to be missed.

author: lentil
title: Great value as a beach accessory set!
review:
This little set offers a great value for a range of cute and useful little accessories. I'm not generally a "Friends" person at all, but this one is really not that "Friend"-ly to begin with, is easy to modify to make it even less so, and offers parts that would be useful to add to any generic beach scene.

Considering its small size and price point, the set comes with a plethora of items and accessories:

  • one minidoll sporting a summery outfit, flip-flops, and a very nice helmet/ponytail hairpiece
  • one pug puppy, with purple motorcycle goggles on her head, and a dog treat printed tile
  • one scooter in lavender, plus bricks for building a sidecar that the pug (or a minifig passenger) can ride on. The sidecar is detachable so you could use this or not. The scooter has a small compartment built onto the back for carrying small cargo (up to 2 1x2 tiles worth)
  • two surfboards: one plain lime green and one white with attractive printing
  • a pair of lime green flippers
  • a brick-built water bottle
  • binoculars
  • a circular tile with life preserver printing
  • a green flag

The main build is a lifeguard chair situated on a little beach near some waves. Really the only thing that screams "Friends" about this build is the 4x4 lavender plate on the chair floor, and this is easy enough to replace with another color (you surely have one lying about), should you desire a more traditional City look. I swapped in a blue plate, which looks great with the orange and lime green. To complete the de-Friending process, you can also replace the magenta flipper holder and flagpole base with a less silly color, and you end up with a little vignette that looks right at home in any traditional City/Coast Guard/Beach scene.

Overall highly recommended for its parts - especially if you can pick it up at a further discount at one of the many "Friends" sales that pop up!

author: Odeinoichus
title: Mia Lacks Uniformity
review:
Set #41306 Mia’s Beach Scooter: Unlike most of the other Friends I believe Mia has had the least consistent of the sets at these price points. She has had a bedroom, a variety show stage with magic tricks, a lemonade stand and an archery stand, now she gets this beach scooter… with Olivia, Emma, Andrea and even Stephanie there is a consistent range of sets at this price point for their favorite hobbies and pastimes.

With Mia she doesn’t seem to have anything aside from liking pets and animals, so most of her sets are a bit Jill-of-all-trades. She’ll do anything and everything and you can have lots of fun with what you get in her sets, but it’s still unfortunate that most of the 12.99$ price point for Mia tends to be so unfocused as if you collect them all you can’t display them all together in her home as well as the other Friends.

That being said, let’s discuss her set from 2017 and see if it’s a decent set or something to ignore and skip over.

Box/Instructions

Box: This box design is what it is, LEGO Friends haven’t changed much about the design since 2012, however this time they have some added artwork on the front with features Mia and Toffee on either side of the front image, which is a nice addition to the overall design showing the Friend character in a nice art style. I like this evolution of the original Friends box design.

Instructions: As I said before the 2017 Friends added more imagery to the back showing the Friends in a playful and fun mood, the rest is still the same however and so you can follow along easily to build the models and look at all the sets from the wave in the back and plan which one to buy next. A serviceable manual design.

Parts

Some beach themed parts are found in this set, including a pair of surfboards and a set of flippers for diving, nothing truly eye catching honestly, if you’re in the market for parts you’d probably be best served with other sets.

Mini-Doll

Mia: There isn’t much to say about Mia, she’s wearing a combination of pants and shirt that we’ve actually seen often before in the past. The only different piece for her here is the helmet with ponytail which she’s wearing while driving her scooter. There is no alternative hair piece for when she’s sitting on her beach seat monitoring for dangers, which is a bit unfortunate, but honestly not so bad.

Toffee the Pug is included with the set and this animal piece is a real gem, I feel that it’s been used before this, but this is my first time with the piece and I love the level of detail in it and how cute they make it appear, they capture the adorable look of this animal quite well. You get some printed dog biscuit pieces and a buildable heart shaped accessory for Mia to hold.

The build

There are two things to build in this set, both of the builds are fun and easy to follow along with, you get to make a small lifeguard seat with a bit of beach and ocean around it and then the titular Beach Scooter, which is a one-person vehicle and side-car for Mia’s pet Pug to ride along with her.

None of the steps were overly difficult and the models are quick and easy to build, with perhaps a bit too much ease of build, this model could be finished in fifteen to twenty minutes, though not necessarily a bad thing for younger builders wanting to start playing as soon as possible, folks preferring more challenging builds may want a meatier product to sink their teeth into.

The completed model

Lifeguard Stand: This build isn’t too terrible, but it is rather on the short side compared to what you’d expect to see from LEGO, the seat is a bit lower to the ground than I’ve seen even in the City Starter Set I reviewed recently, also it features some nice accessories, there’s two flippers, a buildable water bottle, a pair of binoculars and a green surf board. The model works fine for what it’s going for, but honestly I feel they could have done a bit better, perhaps add a spot for the pug to sit as well so that Mia doesn’t have to leave him on the scooter.

Beach Scooter: The main scooter is built using a sculpted piece, which we’ve seen before, in fact I think she used a different coloured one to deliver her Lemonade from the Lemonade Stand set released a few years ago. The majority of the building revolves around making a space for the Pug to fit, a very nicely built up side-car that accommodates her pet and the second surf board with the printed detailing on it. It’s a great model and I feel the target audience will love getting Mia to ride off to help rescue another Friend with her pet.

Overall opinion

This set is pretty great for what it is, Mia and her Pug Toffee are great looking and the models work great, they also fit in quite nicely with the beach themed sets of the past, Emma’s Lifeguard Post and Olivia’s Speed Boat would look great next to this one in anybody’s collection. I strongly recommend this set.
